clinical_study.brief_title: Breast Milk and Congenital Gastrointestinal Disorders
clinical_study.official_title: Effects of an All Breast Milk Diet on Enteral Feeding Outcomes of Neonates With Congenital Gastrointestinal Disorders

brief_summary.textblock: This study aims to identify whether an all breast milk (BM) diet would improve outcomes in neonates with congenital gastrointestinal disorders (CGD) by facilitating an earlier transition off of parenteral nutrition (PN).

primary_outcome.time_frame: Post initial feeding (Up to ten days)
primary_outcome.description: The length of hospital stay described as the number of days spent in the hospital after the initial breast milk feeding.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Post initial feeding (Up to ten days)
secondary_outcome.description: The number of days to achieve full enteral feeding after the initial breast milk feeding.

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of days of parenteral nutrition
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Post initial feeding (Up to ten days)
secondary_outcome.description: The total number of days parenteral nutrition is required.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Post initial feeding (Up to ten days)
secondary_outcome.description: The difference in average bilirubin level will be compared between the non-breast milk diet (retrospective control group) and the breast milk diet group.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Post initial feeding (Up to ten days)
secondary_outcome.description: The number of sepsis episodes will be compared between the non-breast milk diet (retrospective control group) and the breast milk diet group.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Post initial feeding (Up to ten days)
secondary_outcome.description: The number of deaths between participants who receive breast milk only diets as compared to the non-breast milk diet (retrospective control group while in the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU).

arm_group.description: Approximately 45 patients with congenital gastrointestinal disorders who were treated in the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) at Children's Healthcare of Atlanta-Egleston from 2012 to 2015, who had non-breast milk (BM) diets will be identified as retrospective controls using the electronic medical records system.

Approximately 45 participants with congenital gastrointestinal disorders who are admitted to the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) will have an exclusively breast milk (BM) diet, fortified with Prolacta if required.

intervention.description: Participants will receive breast milk (fortified with Prolacta if required per doctor's discretion) for regular feedings while in the neonatal intensive care unit (NICU).

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Neonates admitted to the Egleston Neonatal intensive care unit (NICU) who have never been fed
- Congenital gastrointestinal abnormalities such as gastroschisis, bowel atresias, malrotation, omphalocele, or meconium ileus
Exclusion Criteria:
- Previous feeding
